13618.post_content:
Browsers ignore:

  • Multiple character spaces (white space)
  • Line breaks (carriage returns)
  • Tabs
  • Unrecognized markup

Text must be marked up meaningfully and accurately (semantically) with HTML tags:

  • Browsers need markup to display content correctly.
  • Markup makes content elements available to scripts and style rules.
  • Markup aids search engines.

13619.post_title: Technology you will use on this course
13619.post_content:
We will use several tools to create our HTML, CSS and JavaScript Code to start with.

We need a text editor to actually input the code into web documents (html, css and javascript files) as well as a browser to view them in. The following applications are what we are going to be using in Next Level.

  • Text Editor - VSCode  (download http://bit.ly/2WUCqa0 ). This is editor we will be using. It is the current industry standard and is cross platform (operating system) compatible. Download this text editor using the link above and install it. The links below are for keyboard shortcuts and using Emmet with helps cut down typing time of code by implementing code snippets. VSCode can also be extended by using plugins. The list of plugins or extensions we will use in this course are in a separate page after this.
    • Windows keyboard shortcuts: http://bit.ly/2Ecp2aa
    • Mac keyboard shortcuts: http://bit.ly/2Echq7k
    • Emmet Cheat Sheet: http://bit.ly/2WUDH0M
  • Web Browser - either Firefox Developer or  Google Chrome browser. These have tools for web development, which are inbuilt and useful. I will be using Firefox Developer for my main browsers as it has many features that I prefer to use that Chrome does not have readily available.
Please install before our first session.

13670.post_content:
HTML stands for HyperText Markup Language.

It is not a programming language it is a markup language similar to what is used in your word processing application like Microsoft Word or Apple Pages.

It is a text file with the suffix of .html

All images and media need to be linked into the document unlike in a desktop publishing application

13672.post_content:
Part A

  • In VS Code, open a new file. Save it as "exercise1.html".
  • Copy and paste the text below into the html file you have just created.
  • View it in your Browser to see how it looks. You will notice that there is no styling, or headings or paragraphs and it is just straight text.
  • In your text editor create a html file called index.html in a folder called WK1-Exercises.
  • Using the emmet shortcut ! inside your new html file, to create the basic structure of this new web page.
  • For the title of this document (inside the <title></title>) ADD the words "Black Goose Bistro"
  • Now copy and paste the text below into the page underneath the opening body tag <body> yet before the closing body tag

Black Goose Bistro

The Restaurant
The Black Goose Bistro offers casual lunch and dinner fare in a relaxed atmosphere. The menu changes regularly to highlight the freshest local ingredients.

Catering
You have fun. We'll handle the cooking. Black Goose Catering can handle events from snacks for a meetup to elegant corporate fundraisers.

Location and Hours
Seekonk, Massachusetts;
Monday through Thursday 11am to 9pm; Friday and Saturday, 11am to midnight

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<title>Black Goose Bistro</title>
</head>

<body>

Black Goose Bistro

The Restaurant
The Black Goose Bistro offers casual lunch and dinner fare in a relaxed atmosphere. The menu changes regularly to highlight the freshest local ingredients.

Catering
You have fun. We'll handle the cooking. Black Goose Catering can handle events from snacks for a meetup to elegant corporate fundraisers.

Location and Hours
Seekonk, Massachusetts;
Monday through Thursday 11am to 9pm; Friday and Saturday, 11am to midnight

</body>

</html>

Part B

  • Using the same file, Use the Emmet shortcut to add the basic HTML Document structure before the text you had just pasted in. (Click inside the document, make sure it has the .html suffix, and then key in ! and either tab or enter straight after it)
  • Change the text in the <title> element to Black Goose Bistro
  • Move the text in to the <body> element.
  • Now it is the time to markup the text in the <body> element:
  • Ensure that you have the text in between the opening and closing tags of the element.
  • For the words "Black Goose Bistro", insert these into a <h1> element
  • For the words "The Restaurant" and "Catering" insert these into their own <h2> elements
  • For the words "Location and Hours" insert these into a <h3> element.
  • The above steps means that we have added headings to our html page. Take a look in the Browser to see how they now look.
  • For the text that is left insert these into their own <p> elements.
  • We will create a list with the information underneath Location and hours. Please take a look at the code below and implement it. You may need to scroll down to see how the code is put in.
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<title>Black Goose Bistro</title>
</head>

<body>

<h1>Black Goose Bistro</h1>

<h2>The Restaurant</h2>
<p>The Black Goose Bistro offers casual lunch and dinner fare in a relaxed atmosphere. The menu changes regularly to highlight the freshest local ingredients.</p>

<h2>Catering</h2>
<p>You have fun. <em>We'll handle the cooking.</em> Black Goose Catering can handle events from snacks for a meetup to elegant corporate fundraisers.</p>

<h2>Location and Hours</h2>
<ul>
<li>Seekonk, Massachusetts;</li>
<li>Monday through Thursday 11am to 9pm;</li> 
<li>Friday and Saturday, 11am to midnight</li>
</ul>

</body>

</html>

Part C

  • Using the same file, we are now going to add in an <img> element for the following image. Please ensure that you have the file structure displayed on the left for your exercise.
  • Downloaded this assets file, uncompress / unzip it and place the blackgoose.png image into the images folder.
  • Above your <h1> element but below the opening <body> tag insert the following code
    <img src="images/blackgoose.png" alt="black goose inside a circle which is the logo" />
  • This code shows the path to the images folder, and the alternate text  for the image.
  • Once you have completed this take a look in the browser to see how it looks.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<title>Black Goose Bistro</title>
</head>

<body>

<img src="blackgoose.png" alt="logo"><h1>Black Goose Bistro</h1>

<h2>The Restaurant</h2>
<p>The Black Goose Bistro offers casual lunch and dinner fare in a relaxed atmosphere. The menu changes regularly to highlight the freshest local ingredients.</p>

<h2>Catering</h2>
<p>You have fun. <em>We'll handle the cooking.</em> Black Goose Catering can handle events from snacks for a meetup to elegant corporate fundraisers.</p>

<h2>Location and Hours</h2>
<ul>
<li>Seekonk, Massachusetts;</li>
<li>Monday through Thursday 11am to 9pm;</li> 
<li>Friday and Saturday, 11am to midnight</li>
</ul>

</body>

</html>

13779.post_content:
Instructions

Download instructions from https://drive.google.com/file/d/1NRnjg0-k9Joh28-Md787PIFd8AzZjA13/view

Content for Bayside Beats

Page 1

Hero Text

Be Where It’s At

San Francisco is one of the most exciting and vibrant cities on the planet. Bayside Beat is here to keep you informed of the best places to see, where to eat, what to do, and where to lay down your weary head after an action-packed day—or night—on the town.

Main Content

Riding the Cable Cars

No visit to San Francisco is complete without a ride on the iconic cable cars that climb up the vertiginous hills of the city. Of the twenty-three lines established between 1873 and 1890, three remain: two routes from downtown near Union Square to Fisherman's Wharf, and a third route along California Street.

The cable cars rely on cables running constantly beneath the road’s surface. The driver—or gripman—uses a lever to grip the cable to pull the car and its passengers up the hill. The gripman requires not only great strength, but also great skill. He needs to know where to release the cable to coast over crossing cables and points. The conductor works in close cooperation with the gripman, operating the brake at the rear of the car to prevent it from running out of control on the downward slopes.

Although the cable cars are now mainly a tourist attraction, they’re still used by local commuters to get to and from work. The California Street line is particularly popular among commuters on weekdays.

Aside Content

Cable Car Tips


A single ride on a cable car costs $6. If you plan to travel around the city, it’s often cheaper to buy a Muni Passport, which gives you unlimited rides on San Francisco’s extensive public transport system, including the cable cars (but not the BART subway system). Even a single-day passport ($14) will save you money if you make a return trip, and stop off to visit Chinatown one way.

There are often long lines at the cable car terminus, particularly on the Powell-Mason and Powell-Hyde routes. If you don’t want to wait, try walking a few stops along the route. The conductor usually leaves a small number of places to pick up passengers on the way. The California Street route is generally less crowded (but not as spectacular).

Download images from Resources section.

Image caption:
The cable car terminus near Union Square

Links:

  • Fisherman’s Wharf - http://www.fishermanswharf.org/
  • Muni Passport - http://www.sfmta.com/cms/mfares/passports.htm
  • Bart Subway - http://www.bart.gov/

Page 2

Main Content

See the Sights of San Francisco

The precipitous hills in San Francisco make it a city best explored by public transport. Grab a Muni Passport, and ride the buses, streetcars, Metro, and—of course—the historic cable cars.
One of the best ways to get familiar with the city is to ride the Powell-Mason or Powell-Hyde cable car from Market Street. This takes you through Union Square, up over Nob Hill, through Chinatown, down to the waterfront at Fisherman’s Wharf. Stop off at Chinatown to soak in the unique atmosphere of the largest Chinatown outside Asia. And if Chinese food sets your mouth watering, there are nearly 200 authentic Chinese restaurants to choose from.
If you prefer seafood, then you’ll love Fisherman’s Wharf. Even if you’re not hungry, just stroll around the waterfront looking at the fishing boats and watching sea lions basking in the sun. Out in the Bay lies Alcatraz (the Rock), once home to notorious criminals, including Al Capone.
To visit Alcatraz, it’s advisable to book the ferry tickets online because they usually sell out about a week in advance. You’re left free to wander around the Rock and the former federal prison. Budget about two and a half hours for the trip, and be prepared for changeable weather.
If you can't get tickets for Alcatraz, take one of the many boat trips around San Francisco Bay. They take you around the Rock and out to the Golden Gate Bridge, another iconic symbol of the city.
Just a few ideas to get you started exploring this fascinating city.

Aside Content

Tourist Information

There’s no shortage of information about what to see while in San Francisco. The San Francisco Visitor Information Center is the official travel and visitors’ guide to the city, with information in 14 languages.
Among the many unofficial sites, the Lonely Planet guide to San Francisco is packed with useful information.

Sightseeing Tours

One way to see the city is on an open-top bus, a hop-on, hop-off service that offers either prerecorded or live commentary. The route goes over the Golden Gate Bridge, giving stunning views across the city (as long as it’s not shrouded in fog!)
If you’re feeling more energetic, several companies offer bicycle rental. You can even cycle across the Golden Gate Bridge on the wide bike path.
And for something completely different… Why not see the city on a Segway?

Image Captions:
The front seat of a cable car affords a great view of the city
Alcatraz—former exclusive residence for notorious criminals

Links
Muni passport http://www.sfmta.com/cms/mfares/passports.htm
Fisherman’s Wharf http://www.fishermanswharf.org/
book the ferry tickets online http://www.alcatrazcruises.com/index.aspx
San Francisco Visitor Information Center http://www.sanfrancisco.travel/
Lonely Planet Guide to San Francisco http://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/san-francisco
open-top bus http://www.bigbustours.com/eng/sanfrancisco/custompage.aspx
see the city on a Segway http://www.electrictourcompany.com/

13912.post_content:
CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheet and the code used is the programming language of design.

CSS is how we add design elements to a webpage so it does not look like a wall of text. These design elements encompass page layouts, custom fonts, layout of individual sections as well as design elements for type/fonts that use visual communication techniques to either reinforce what the words are saying or highlight a particular meaning.

CSS rules can be set in three areas of a web page.

  1. Within the actual element tag using the property name "style". This is called inline styles
<p style="property: value">this is a paragraph example</p>
  1. Within the head section of the web page using the html element tag <style> </style> where you put the rules for the styles in-between the opening and closing element tags. You can also add the <style> element in the body section before you want to use it on your html elements. These are called internal or embedded styles
<head>
     ...
     <style>
         p{property: value;}
     <style>
</head>
<body>
<p>this is a paragraph</p>
<style>
   h2{property: value;}
</style>
<h2>this is a heading</h2>

</body>
  1. In an external file with the extension ".css" where you list your rules as text. This external file can be linked to your html file by using the <link> element .
<head>
     ...
     <link href="path/to/css_document" rel="stylesheet/css" />
</head>

Specificity Cascade and Inheritance

Cascade

The strength of CSS is the cascade and this can be a little bit of trouble understanding. Not only does the cascade occur within a set of CSS style rules, it can override a previous style of lesser importance if there is a conflict. Cascade is all about the importance of a style in relation to the elements. There is a specific order in which the cascade occurs:

  1. Author inline styles
  2. Author embedded styles (aka: internal style sheets)
  3. Author external style sheet
  4. User style sheet
  5. Default browser style sheet

The above list is in order of most important to less. We have already seen the default browser styles in our HTML session. A user can update the browser styles through their browser settings, and the Author refers to you as the author of the styles for the website.

Another part of the cascade that matters is the order of the rules. Take for example the following rules that are in conflict with each other.

1. p {color: black;}
2. ul {border: 1px solid pink;}
3. p.intro {color: brown;}
4. p {color: red;}

1. What would the final colour of the paragraph be after apply these rules?
ANS: If just looking at the paragraph tags then the paragraphs without the class intro will be red. This is because Rule #4 is last and will override Rule #1 due to order in the style sheet.

2. Which is the more specific rule for paragraphs?
ANS: Rule #3 is the most specific because it specifies all paragraphs that also have the class attribute value of intro.

Inheritance

Inheritance refers to the style an element may inherit from a parent style when no specific style has been added to that element. Inheritance normally applies to document text and the main parent of all those elements in the document tree is <html> element. This affects all displayed elements within the body, and the font property is mainly what is inherited. This is why we mainly use the <body> element to attach font styles.

Styles are not inherited are mainly those elements that deal with appearance. These are properties like borders, as it does not make sense to dictate their look universally in the web page.

Specificity

Because we want to have styles that conflict to help us style our web pages, specificity helps with working out which rule applies where. Understanding how this works is paramount in how we write style sheets and use the properties available to us.

Selectors have different values of importance (or specificity). Here is the short list (listed in order of importance):

  1. id selectors
  2. class and pseudo class selectors
  3. element selectors

If multiple CSS rules conflict with one another, the most important or specific selector is the one that will apply. This is calculated by the order of appearance in an element.

Graphic way of seeing specificity at work.

image from https://css-tricks.com/specifics-on-css-specificity/

13961.post_content:
setting up our HTML

Using the finished code for our Black Goose Bistro home page, lets change our html code to add some classes and ids that we will be using for our CSS.

To start with let's put our styles as embedded style sheet in the head. I do this whilst I am planning my CSS styles so that I can see the effect. I will then transfer the styles into an external style sheet so that all the site has access to these global styles.

Adding the CSS

Next we will set up the header container, the main container and the footer container to all be the same width by adding the width to the style element. The width value used is VW which stands for Viewport Width. 1vw is equivalent to 1/100th of the browser viewport width. Setting the width to 100vw means that the containers will stretch across the whole width of the browser.

Taking a look at the style rules on the right, add classes as needed to the html so that we can apply the styles that are there.

In this set of style rules, we have used flexbox properties to set up various containers, change the lists so that there is no list-style (bullets) as well as provide a border around the navigation list items. We have also set background colour for the header and footer.

You will notice that we have nested the use of flexbox to achieve the look.

Extending Yourself

Now that you have this on your index page, you can add to your other pages by taking the rules between the <style> element tags and pasting it to a text file called styles.css. This file lives in a folder called styles. link the other pages to this style sheet to apply the styles across the Black Goose website

 ...
 <style>
    header, main, footer{
      width: 80vw;
      margin: 0 auto;

  
    }
    header{
      background-color: darkkhaki;
      display: flex;
      flex-direction: column;
      justify-content: center;
      align-items: center;
    }
    ul.main-menu, ul.business-address{
      list-style: none;
      display:flex;
      justify-content: space-around;
    }

    ul.main-menu li{
      padding: .5rem;
      border: 1px solid darkkhaki;
      flex: 1;
    }
    main{
      display: flex;
      justify-content: center;
      align-items: center;
    }
    main article{
      flex: 1;
      padding: 2vw;
    }
    footer{
      background-color: darkkhaki;
      padding: 2vw 0;
    }
</style>
13961.curriculum_name: Adding in Some CSS for Layout

13962.post_content:
Taking what you have learned from the flexbox lessons, create the styles to apply to the Bayside Beats. If you have not done the previous Test Yourself activity you can download a set of starter files.

Setting up structure

After completing the site as semantic HTML, the next step is to create the css layout and typography for the site. This will be done by adding block level elements to divide the page adding layout rules as well as typography and colours.

  1. Around the lines 11 - 30 place the <header> element
    1. Give the <h1> a class of ‘header_title’
    2. Inside this block around the <ul> element place a <nav> element. Give the the <ul> element a class of ‘nav_bar ‘and the first list <li> a class of ‘active’
    3. All the <a> elements are to have a class of ‘nav_link’
  2. From line 32(or 33) put a <section> element and give it a class of ‘hero’
    1. For the image give it a class of ‘hero_image’
    2. Around the <h2> and <p> elements put an article element and give this a class of hero_article, the <h2> a class of ‘hero_article-title’ and the paragraph a class of ‘hero_article-text’
  3. After the closing section element for the ‘hero’ create the <main> element around all the content until the paragraph containing the copyright statement.
  4. Around the content for ‘Riding The Cable Cars’ put in a section with an id of ‘content’ and then an article element nested inside this section element
  5. The content under the heading “Cable Car Tips” is to be put inside an <aside> element with an id of “sidebar”
  6. With the image of the cable car and the caption underneath transform into the following code:
<figure class="content-figure">
<img src="images/cable_car1.jpg" alt="cable car union square" />
 <figcaption>
  <p>The cable car terminus near Union Square</p>
</figcaption>          
</figure>
Layout

To Start with will will use flexbox CSS

  1. Create a <style> element in the head container after the element. All styling will be placed inside this element.
  2. Using the universal selector, set box-sizing to border-box, margins and padding to 0; This will apply to all elements on the page.
  3. In the <style> element create a body selector rule that creates a 1 column flexbox
    •     display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          justify-content: start;
  4. Center the text in the <header> by using text-align;
  5. Create an inline navigation by creating another flexbox with the contents justified with space-around.
  6. With the main content create another flex-box. This one justifies content with space-around.
  7. Article has 3 times as much space as the aside. So the article selector has a flex of 3 and the aside has a flex of 1;

This provides a basic layout of the page using flex-box. The only section of the page that still needs to be styled is that of the hero section. This we will do with positioning.  The image needs to be 100% of the width of the page. This can be done with either 100% or 100VW. The parent hero element is the element with the class of .hero . The hero article needs to be in the top right hand section of the image so we use absolute positioning along with coordinates to ensure that it is sitting where we need it to be. I have given you the code using positioning which we will change to grid next session.

/*using positioning for hero*/
.hero{
    position: relative;
}
.hero_image{
    width: 100%;
    object-fit: cover;
}

.hero_article{
    position: absolute;
    top: 10vw;
    left: 70vw;
    right: 5vw;
}

This has now added a layout to Bayside Beat home page
13962.curriculum_name: Adding in Some CSS for Layout

13963.post_content:
CSS for Layout

Using flexbox for pages and page elements

Back in the bad old days we use to use tables to cut up website mockup images and place them in the table. Then we got floats positioning which can be highly confusing for anyone not use to it. Now we have flexbox CSS and Grid CSS which allows us to have more control over our page designs.

Intro to Flexbox

Flexbox CSS was introduced so that we could have control over the width and height of elements. It is most suited for components within a web page such as navigation, galleries, columns.

Flexbox is also directionally agnostic meaning it can layout elements either horizontally or vertically. Flexbox only looks at one dimension that being vertically in a column or horizontally in a row.

The image to the right is a poster from CSS-Tricks that explains different property rules that can be used for flexbox. You can explore more through the pdf presentation of flexbox available for download.

Flexbox can be used for navigation bars - Exercise 1 - Flexbox Navigation and it can be used to set up page structures although it is best if Grid CSS is used for the page layout.

Learning Flexbox

Flexbox Froggy

Learn how each property of flexbox works by playing the game and moving Froggy to the right lillypad.

Play Flexbox Froggy

Flexbox Tutorial (CSS): Real Layout Examples

View this Youtube tutorial on some of the common way to use flexbox in layout

View the Tutorial
